message.content:
cs.SI, cs.CL, cs.SD, cs.IR, cs.LG. 

This paper deals with the problem of clustering content in social media, specifically Twitter, which falls under the scope of social media analysis. The paper uses natural language processing techniques to identify and cluster memes, which is a subfield of computational linguistics. The paper also incorporates network analysis to take into account the social network dimension of the data, which falls under the scope of social network analysis. Therefore, the most likely arXiv CS sub-category for this paper is cs.SI (Social and Information Networks). 

The paper also uses natural language processing techniques to identify and cluster memes, which falls under the scope of computational linguistics, making cs.CL (Computation and Language) another likely sub-category. 

The paper also uses clustering algorithms and memory mechanisms, which falls under the scope of machine learning, making cs.LG (Machine Learning) another likely sub-category. 

The paper also deals with the problem of event detection, which falls under the scope of information retrieval, making cs.IR (Information Retrieval) another likely sub-category. 

Finally, the paper deals with the problem of clustering data in a streaming scenario, which falls under the scope of software engineering, making cs.SD (Software Engineering) another likely sub-category.
